newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila banks stay away from T-bill market.
newsitem.headline: Manila banks stay away from T-bill market.

text.p: Philippine banks stayed away from the secondary market of T-bills as the local currency continued to be dogged by further weakness, traders said.
"Today, it's been dull compared to yesterday. People are just looking at the peso," a foreign bank trader said.
The peso has been hounded by the turmoil in the region's currencies. It fell to a low of 29.85 to dollar in morning deals.
Traders also said they want to see whether liquidity would tigthen after the central bank raised liquidity reserves to five percent from four percent effective today.
The central bank made this move to mop up liquidity to moderate the impact of lower overnight rates on the peso.
The central bank dropped on Thursday its overnight borrowing rate to 14 percent from 18 percent.
Traders said they expected the central bank to raise liquidity reserves further if the peso hits the record low of 30 to the dollar.
The average interbank call loan rate slipped to 14.0625 percent from 14.09375 percent. Volume thinned to 8.12 billion pesos from 15.67 billion.
Out of the 43 participating financial institutions, 22 were lenders.
